reviewText:
VRC Pro is an RC simulation game from developer Virtual Racing Industries that is currently available on Steam as well as on the VRC Pro website. VRC Pro gives you access to the world of modern RC cars and racing and provides a method of training for amateurs and veterans of RC racing alike. While it may be intimidating at first VRC Pro is an excellent way to get in to the world of RC motorsport.

A word of warning, don't expect this to be an RC racing game because that's not what it is, this is a simulation game and a realistic one at that. Also I'd just like to say I've never really raced RC cars in real life, I used to own some RC cars which I used to drive around but that's about as far as my experience with RC cars goes.

+Great graphics
+Realistic physics
+All of the included cars (15) and all of the included tracks (22) are real
+A good variety of different types of car and different types of track
+A huge amount of customization options for the cars included as well as the ability to create your own from scratch
+Has gamepad support as well as support for real RC controllers (adapter required)
+The controls at first seem complex and difficult to use but once you get the hang of them they're great
+Great performance
+A fixed camera view as well as an up close 'following camera'
+There is a practice mode for races, helps to familiarise you with a track before you take part in the main race
+Practice cars (AI) are very good
+Several different game modes both offline and online
+Good amount of people online and I believe it can be played with people who own the non-Steam version also
+Provides a good way to enjoy RC racing without having to spend a lot of money on a real RC car
+The developer is active on the Steam forums

+/-You pretty much have to play this with a controller, personally I'm fine with that but I know a lot of people get annoyed if they can't play with KB&M

-You can't pause the game even when playing offline
-Some of the tracks seen on the Steam store page aren't included in the Steam version of the game
-Not all of the tracks have the option for you to practice or race against AI, kind of annoying if you're like me and only want to play the game offline
-It's not very begginer friendly and it only has a very simple tutorial

Verdict:
8

A great way to learn how to race RC cars with realistic physics, great graphics, a fair few cars to drive and a number of tracks to drive them on. If you have any interest in racing RC cars then this is definitely a game you should pick up.

***This review was written using a key provided by the Developer for review purposes***

El K.

reviewText: Lovin this game, so realistic and 100% spot on to the real thing and one of my best games to date. The problem is i decided to buy this game through Steam only to find that all the extra DLC like cars and tracks etc thats on the official VRC Pro website version is its not availible through Steam and once you have brought it through Steam you can no longer buy the extra DLC from the site as it becomes linked to Steam only. Anyone looking to buy this game at the moment and wanting extra DLC i would suggest buying it directly from the official VRC Pro website as you will be able to buy all the extras and addons. I am hoping that all the DLC is going to be availible via steam, so Steam please hurry it up and get all the DLC added, so until then im just gona have to stick with the limited stuff from this steam version at the moment.

reviewText: VRC Pro is absolutely fantastic. You can start off with an XBox controller, however to get the full experience, you really need to get a USB interface and hook up your own radio / receiver. I'm getting 125 fps on the controller and the feeling of driving a real RC car is just fantastic. Not only is it great fun, but also a superb training tool for this newbie who is currently building a TLR 22v2 for 17.5T spec racing.

reviewText:
I am very impressed by a game that had been out/in development for so long and the work put into it shows.

Pros:
-Very realistic
-Real cars and tracks
-Online races/esport type matches as well as series (haven't touched these yet as my skills are lacking so far but look fun)
-Very in-depth custiomization (body, parts, aerodynamics, ride height, shocks, balance, steering, etc...)
-Punishes you for bad habits
-Can use a real rc controller (need to buy an adapter sold separately)
-Has been out/in development for ~14 years, it shows

Cons:
-Slightly misleading info on steam. The videos/pics show some tracks not yet availible in steam version and felt slightly slighted by the fact I thought I would be getting some of the ones in the videos/pics. After reading their forums and the steam forums it seems they are aware of some of these things and are fixing them. The other tracks from what I gathered will be released as a deluxe" dlc. I am dissapointed that $40 did not get get me the "whole package" or what I was expecting. HOWEVER this is a SIM and a polished one at that and I completely agree with their asking price (for now).
-Will be fixing steam/non steam compatabilty or previous buyer issues. (more forum info)
-Wish more tracks were included
-Is an older game
recommended: other than graphics it really dosen't show
hoursPlayed:
and the graphics are not bad by any means.

Conclusion:
-Definitely recommend this game to anyone interested in a sim rc experience or anyone who has had an rc car.
-DO YOUR RESEARCH on what you will get with steam version/non steam license. Steam version contains more than enough to really enjoy this game I just personally wish there were more tracks included. Everything seems like it will make it's way over to steam and the playerbase will only grow from that.
-Asking price is fair.
-Use a gamepad at the very least if not a real rc controller (xbox 360 controller worked fine for me)"

reviewText:
Do NOT waste your time and money on this crap:

1. The multiplayer community for this Steam version is completely DEAD. I tried to find an MP match around 10pm EST, but there were only 4 players online, I'm not kidding. Just 4. And according to Steam Charts, the average number of players since Feb 2016 has been about 7. The MP community is DEAD.

2. There have been some players having launch / technical issues with the game. However, the developer has never answered their questions (you can easily find these threads in the discussion forum). Another irresponsible developer who doesn't care about the Steam community anymore (probably due to poor sales, obviously). Even the developer regards this crap as ABANDONWARE, why should anyone buy it ffs?

3. The game automatically turned OFF my anti-virus software when I was playing. It happened twice already and so I'm sure it's another technical issue related to the game.

Stay away from this stinky piece of garbage. The MP is completely dead and the developer doesn't care about the Steam community anymore.

Haven't even gotten into the multi-player races or custom car builds yet and already worth the money to me.

reviewText:
Disclaimer : Base game was provided via a review code by the developer. I've spent some considerable time providing feedback and suggestions to said developer, which has resulted in the implementation of the deluxe packs as seen in the DLC section of the store page, his willingness to adapt and provide new ways for players to get involved and experience this game should be seen as a pure positive, and I purchased the deluxe cars pack as a measure of support. Developers who act inclusively should always be supported in such a manner.

This isn't your father's RC game, this isn't Re-Volt either...
With that out of the way, let's get some misconceptions out of the way, what VRC-Pro is and is not. First off, it's not a casual racing game. This isn't a knockabout toybox racer like say Toybox Turbos" or "Blazerush". Whilst VRC-PRO deals with miniature racing cars

reviewText:
FIRST IMPRESSIONS:

I had a few fast Traxxxas remote control cars as a kid and this reminds me of it. It seems to have some elements of Trackmania, but much more difficult and sim emphasis over arcade. My biggest issues so far is that due to lack of players, im often just doing time trails racing myself without competition which can get DULL+BLAND!  MP IS DEAD ***SO DEV ADD AI PLEASE*** or may change my thumbs up to a down!!!!

This is a game that will take some time getting use to the controls, perspectives (although F2 can give you the car POV rather than a controller on the sidelines). Lots of customization options, but the menus can be a bit annoying or difficult to maneuver at first and lots of content is off limits or expensive DLC. Its challenging, very fast cars on small windy tracks overall which is cool. The physics are good but the gamepad and controls are limited. I do like using the dpad to steer similiar to real life controls but R1/R2 would be good options with braking too. I noticed some cars dont have reverse though requiring the annoying voice and space bar to reset, with no options on the gamepad to do so!

Graphics are decent, although the people are cardboard cut outs holograms literally lol, I don't care though. They have a few glictches but nothing big. Load times can be a bit long even on a good pc and connection. Now all we need is a robot wars game where you craft your own machine, i guess that is twisted metal lol.

With a few fixes (controls and add AI to races) and if DLC is more affordable its a solid niche game for fans of the sim racing genre. I recommend when its on sale for casuals as myself. I got the Offroad Tracks #2 DLC with 5 extra and bigger tracks for 10% off so $9 which suggest checking out. I can tell they put ample effort into ths game.

reviewText:
Pros:
Good simulator that works quite well as a game.

Cons:
It might be nice to see more vehicles, but not at the expense of detail.

Comments:
This may not be for someone who wants just to add another racing game to their library and lacks understanding of what is what in R/C. If you are willing to learn this is a great game to help do that since there is so much detail.
I have a history where I was really into electric R/C racing for a few years (10+ years ago). This is my re-introduction to the sport since I do not have easy access to supplies to get back into the hobby. I think to appreciate this game you need to go into it with the mentality that this is a simulator first and foremost, not a game. Thus, I can imagine that tweaking the many parameters for each unique vehicle and component must be a monumental task. Therefore I take my prior R/C training experience an apply it here: I only used to race stock class for the time I spent in the hobby. Why? Because the general skills that are transferrable from class to class do not depend on having the exact setup that you have. If you have a faster motor to begin with you will just spend all day crashing and not having a good time without understanding why. Stock or Spec classes let you get the feel for how you should be driving while making it more approachable. I am again only tinkering around in spec class until I get really comfortable with the Spec classes using lower power motors since you can learn how to handle the car (or SC truck in my case) for the specific track. Once you can race stock class very confidently then moving up to the hotter motors can make sense. This games makes it so that faster does not equal better. A good driver with a stock setup can do quite well against someone who is not such a good driver using the fastest and best setup. As it stands I am mainly playing in the electric short course 1/10 scale class, so I am not too familiar with nitro or road racing. I have tried nitro, and it is an unfamiliar beast for me. I have tried road and I do not have any interest in the class.
Without some sort of controller or game pad the game is not worth getting. I am using an XBox 360 controller which is quite nice, I hope to get the USB adaptor to try using an actual radio transmitter soon. Make sure to calibrate the dead zone since the controls are much less forgiving than in other games.
Edit: I now have had the USB adaptor and use it with a Spektrum SR210 reciever. This requires cutting some of the plastic on the USBs plug to get rid of a corner so that it will plug into the SR210. It works great and I highly reccomend this.

reviewText:
Updated Review, Thumbs Up (28 Aug 15):
In short, I used to take issue with the long-standing fact that not all content was available to owners of the Steam release of VRC-Pro, and that the various platforms were not at parity with one another.  That issue has now been largely resolved, in the form of an all-inclusive DLC which unlocks everything for the life of the product.  The full package doesn't come cheap, but I feel the asking price isn't unreasonable considering the niche market, licensed content, and comparitive pricing of other simulation dlc (e.g. DCS World, The Pinball Arcade, etc.)  In every other regard, I continue to feel that VRC-Pro achieves its aim of providing a realistic simulation of and training tool for rc motorsports.  So the devs have delivered, and fair is fair - I would now recommend VRC-Pro to all rc enthusiasts, including those who prefer Steam as their gaming platform of choice.


Original Review, Thumbs Down (18 June 2015):

I would like to rate VRC Pro positively - I really would.  But I can't at this moment in time, and I'll elaborate as to why, with the hope that I can change this rating in the future.  Do you see the 15th of June (2015) update posted here on Steam with a video of offroad track Psycho Nitro Blast 6"?  You can't race that track if you own VRC Pro on Steam rather than the Freemium/Subscription version.  Or many

reviewText: This game is really cool. I remember, as a kid I would play RC cars with my dad. We had quite a little collection. When I first started this game I was a little skeptical, but once I started racing all the memories flooded back. It really feels exactly like the real thing. It's amazing. And then I did a few rounds with some of the more professional cars that I never got around to racing myself as a kid (although I would look at them for hours). Wow. And so many customization options.\n\nNext thing I'm going to do is hook up my old RC controller. Then it'll really be like the real thing. I can't wait for the devs to start releasing the DLC!

reviewText: If you're not a fan of R/C cars, you probably won't like this title. When I first started on this simulator, I didn't have the adapter to use my transmitter with it, so I was using a gamepad. Although there are some people within the VRC community who use a gamepad (and are pretty good with them...) I found it extremely difficult to control and to me, it just didn't feel right. Everything about the simulation is pretty much spot on with how it is in real life, aside from the occasional glitches that are to be expected with any software, One of the things I like about this title is, when you crash your car (and you will crash...I still crash...a lot), you don't have to worry about breaking anything. That's good because R/C car parts can get expensive.

reviewText:
It's an RC simulator and there aren't really any other games doing what this one tries to do. You get access to various scales of RCs, offroad and onroad, gas and nitro. Hell, you can even build your RC from the ground up and choose all the various parts from licensed manufacturers. I would view it mostly as a training tool / pure simulator. You enter events and are trying to get the best times on the leaderboards and compete against other players' ghosts. You can have collisions on or off but there are no AI bots in this game. It's a great game for what it is as long as you research it a bit and know what it's trying to be.

REVIEW: https://youtu.be/JgRlBmV4vMc

DLC OVERVIEW: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2bnvZe1I2Hk

VRC USB TRANSMITTER ADAPTER: https://youtu.be/0ED-50htuPI

reviewText: More of a simulator than a game, the amount of detailed customization options and technical terminoloy being presented to someone who is not familiar with the sport of RC car racing was a little imtimidating. However, it isn't too terribly difficult to get started with it and it really became a lot of fun once I got the hang of it. It does a decent job of explaining what configuration settings do what for the car do. I've found it's been fun and interesting to learn what all there is to the world of RC racing. I think this is a good game / simulator for both newbies like me and of course good for people who actually know what they're doing. I would say it was a bit difficult at first to play, but after enough practice and getting the hang of it, I've gotten a lot better and have been enjoying it a good bit.

reviewText:
So with the few hours I got into this game I had my doubts I liked the Serious Revolt I know its not the same company that made the game but however they are pretty similar. Graphics are good online play seems to work and somewhat active people come and go. I only had 1 random crash because I hit my spacebar to hard or something the game crashed but quickly loaded back up. Fun game if you like RC cars and Racing. Has an ingame chat for online play and lets you play single player online practice".

Pros
Fun
Enjoyable to play with others
Somewhat realistic
Good Graphics
Very few crashes

Cons
Engines on the RC Cars can get rather annoying the high pitch sound they make but they do sound close to that in real life.
Not alot of people play online anymore for some reason I have rarely experinced any issue playing online
Game crashed when hitting the spacebar to flip the car back over but so far only happened once.

Well this is what I experinced in the few hours I have logged into the game so far I will continue playing until I get bored lol.  Still a fun game even with the very little ammount of people playing not sure why that is dispute with developers or people just got sick of racing games I dunno."

reviewText: ... love it. used to race a .21 buggy. this game has lot of customization.... but one part of making cars in life, is to change out parts like a-arms chassis parts braces wheels rims wings bodies. the do have a few motors and wheels/tires. but  should b able to choose if u want aluminum parts or rpm or stock plastic.  all these things play a huge part in ur real life car so u should b able todo so on the game.... but past that the game is about as close to really driving a rc as iv ever been.  overall great game. dlc a lil expensive.  lots of tracks and different types of cars lots of online events changing all the time.  i would recomend it to anyone who wants to rip[ rc's without paying all the little payments for broken parts and fuel... all i could ask for in this gameis couple things like, crawlers they are fun in real life. more selection of brand name cars.... like traxxas,hpi, team durango, axial, rpm, integy, rc4wd, and the ability to swap parts from a-arms to wing mounts, minimal customization on the cars... but i still say its the best way to race without having to go out and do it in person

reviewText: I really wanted to like this game, but I just couldn't. The UI is horrible, the menues are unintuitive, the tutorial doesn't explain anything other than basic driving controls, the game is poorly optimised and takes ages to load, the game is nearly unplayable without a controller (the game's description doesn't mention this), and lastly, the part selection for buggies (the thing I was looking most forward to driving) is not very extensive.\nLuckily, I had only played for 1.5 hours, so I was able to get a full refund.

reviewText: I would recomend this simulator (WARNING:THIS IS NOT A GAME) if you are at least able to use a game pad with it, preferably with a Dualshock 4 and the Input Mapper driver, so that you can fine tune the properties of the analogue sticks/triggers. Most importantly
date: I am having a lot of fun with it."
